message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests the formation of a thrombus. The patient’s recent surgery and sudden onset of symptoms suggest the most likely cause is a thromboembolism. Pulmonary ischemia, pulmonary hypertension, and pulmonary passive congestion may also result from thromboembolism, but they are not the primary pathogenesis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests thromboembolism as the most likely cause. Pulmonary ischemia and passive congestion would not result in fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery. Pulmonary hypertension may result in pulmonary artery remodeling, but it would not cause fibrous connective tissue around the lumen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests pulmonary embolism, which is caused by thromboembolism. The recent surgery and sudden onset of shortness of breath also support this diagnosis. The other options are less likely to cause this specific pathology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recent surgery and sudden shortness of breath followed by cardiac arrest suggests the most likely cause of death was a pulmonary embolism, which is consistent with the presence of fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery observed in the lung tissue. This finding can be seen in cases of thromboembolism. Pulmonary ischemia, hypertension, and passive congestion can also cause lung tissue changes, but thromboembolism is the most likely cause in this case given the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests the presence of a thromboembolism. This is a common complication following orthopedic surgeries and can lead to acute hypoxic respiratory failure. Pulmonary ischemia and congestion are possible sequelae of a thromboembolism. Pulmonary hypertension can also be a complication of thromboembolism but would not present with fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests the presence of organization of thrombosis, which supports the most likely pathogenesis of thromboembolism. The patient’s recent surgery also increases the risk of developing venous thromboembolism, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and subsequent acute hypoxic respiratory failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery is a key finding for thromboembolism. The patient's recent surgical history suggests an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis, which can lead to pulmonary embolism. Pulmonary ischemia, pulmonary hypertension, and pulmonary passive congestion would not typically present with this particular histological finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests pulmonary embolism. The history of recent surgery and sudden onset of shortness of breath supports this diagnosis. All other options do not explain the observed histological findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery most likely indicates the formation of a thrombus, which then resulted in thromboembolism causing acute hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient’s recent surgery and immobility increases the risk of thromboembolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fibrous connective tissue around the lumen of the pulmonary artery suggests chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), which develops from recurrent embolization of pulmonary arteries. The history of recent surgery further supports this diagnosis, as surgical procedures and immobilization are known risk factors for the development of deep venous thrombosis and subsequent thromboembolism.
